content.rendered:
Plenty of minimal, smart, and expertly produced designs today with work from Auckland, Guadalajara, and London.

M11 by Inhouse

M11 is an upscale hair salon in Auckland, New Zealand, with a killer, minimalist logo by local firm Inhouse: The “1”s in “11” are made from the same exact shape as the right part of the “M”. The result is a simple and elegant logo but with a very distinct visual edge that comes from the irregular-shaped “1”s. This is one of the rare cases where the underlying grid is a pleasure to see as it reveals the tight construction and design reasoning behind the logo. There is not much in application but that’s not a problem as the strength of this project is the logo alone, which is a cut above the rest. (Get it? Salon? “Cut”? Yeah, I know, know). See full project (Via BP&O)

Dieresis by Comité Central

Dieresis — Umlaut in English, as in ü — is an art gallery in Guadalajara, Mexico, that chose the diacritical mark as its name for the change it gives an existing sound, much like art provides a different view on ordinary things. The logo, designed by local firm Comité Central is literally an umlaut, two dots. On their own they pay off nicely on the name but in application they extend the concept quite beautifully by die-cutting the umlaut in the print materials that act as windows to see beyond what’s directly in front of you, as they explain it, and as I buy it. The deadpan design approach serves the applications well and gives the gallery a confident air of authority. See full project

Hedeker by Socio Design

Hedeker, based in Lincolnshire, IL, offers wealth management, financial planning, and tax services to individuals, families, and foundations. How they ended up with an identity from London-based Socio Design is a case of good wealth management I suppose. Good for them, because it’s gorgeous. The wordmark is a little dry and the icon is nice and ambiguous but the applications are beautifully done in a rich, luxurious palette of dark blue, brown, and copper that looks exclusive and luxurious but not pretentious. The typography all around is impeccable and the bonus dot pattern is, well, a great bonus. See full project
